reviewText: If you know the studio albums of VNV Nation, never saw them live and have not seen the DVD yet... you will be in for a big surprise. The VNV Nation you knew are dead, long live VNV Nation, the very different VNV Nation.The sound is rougher and yes, the beats are harder (what excited me as an old school raver from the early 90's) and Ronan's voice does also not sound that pretty anymore. What you get in return is pure energy you can feel when it grabs you and pulling you right into it.I saw VNV live three times already and the most listened to VNV CD I have, is my homemade rip of the audio from this DVD, which I asked them to replace more than once (Email, MySpace) by the first real, original and legal VNV Nation Live Album.So far no luck and my self made live album has to be sufficient for now or the DVD itself when you are home and have a TV and DVD player.
summary: Forget what know about the VNV Nation studio albums
Title: N/A

reviewText: This showcase on electronic duo VNV Nation is OK but thats it. It's just OK. Nothing major here & definitely not something you can't catch on YouTube or Pandora with the same visual or aural impact. This was clearly filmed during VNV Nation's height of popularity in the gothic - industrial scene back in the late 90's, early 2000's, & covering their first three albums. I'm not so sure these guys are still such a groundbreaking nor driving force in the industrial or ebm scene these days but then again, I haven't been following  that "scene" for many years now. While many of these songs still sound great today & live, & especially if you enjoy electronic music, & the dark aesthetics they represent, this still looks fan made, & isn't very interesting outside of the live performance collages. Nor are the silly & almost retarded behind the scenes excerpts showing them on their "future perfect" tour. Great music & great band but sort of a crappy DVD release & certainly not worth the $20. Your better off seeing them live, on Youtube, or just hearing their songs on your ipod. This is for completist's only. Past Not Worth it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I watched my partner's copy of "PastPerfect" last night and frankly I'm surprised that "VNV Nation" ever sold out a gig again after they released this DVD.Good god, it really is a dreadful example of a live show.The editors have quite clearly had to splice together about four different gigs to put together even this travesty of a performance. This coupled with the fact that the singer is out of time with "his own" music, forgets all of "his own" lyrics and seems to think that repeatedly yelling the final word of every chorus (whilst repeatedly imploring the crowd to "show me your hands") constitutes some sort of  stagecraft gives you some idea of what you can expect.Seriously, its like watching the drunken exhortations of a hyperventilating farmer from County Kerry who has stumbled upon a Karaoke machine after spending rather too long in the beer tent at a livestock fair.Were there any rehearsals? I've seen tighter bits of loose string.I saw "VNV Nation" on the "Future Perfect" tour back in 2001 and I don't remember them being this bad. Then again, perhaps I was just very, very drunk at the time.That said, If you enjoy watching musical car crashes, then consider this an absolutely essential purchase.
summary: The Best Karaoke DVD Of All Time...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Good value being 2 DVD's and 1 CD in the package (and a poster and a sticker).I think I see why it took them so long to produce -- the videos of the live shows are excellent.  It's not just one long video of one concert, it's actually a mishmash of the best shots from the best shows with what I believe may be a mix of sound from live action and recorded dubbing (the recorded sound is a lot better quality than I expected coming from concerts -- I think it actually says something about this during the intro).So basically it's like the best concert you've ever seen, with better sound.And it's great to finally see the guys behind the music and hear them talk about music issues, as well as a nice "Making of Futureperfect" which shows you some of the technical aspects (hardware/software) of how that album was made.  I found that piece (one of the things on disc 2) to be particularly interesting.I haven't watched the whole thing yet (it's a whole lot of material) but I'm already really happy with the purchase.  This is a quality release.I would suggest this isn't JUST for hard-core VNV fans, it's something I think anyone who's into this type of music would get a lot out of.  Most of the interviews aren't dealing with VNV specific topics, but more general topics about the challenges and goals of artists in this genre.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am thoroughly impressed and sated by this 3 disc release by VNV Nation. This is so far their first and only release for a DVD. This was the special edition 'Pastperfect' DVD that covered the 2001-2002 Futureperfect Tour of Europe and the United States. This is great value for money and a must for any true-blue VNV Nation fan. This DVD comes with 2 DVD discs and a bonus CD for computer content. I will go cover all three discs separately;Disc 1: Live Concert Footage from Europe and the USAThere are 12 songs included (11 if you don't take 'Intro' into consideration). These include the hits of 'Kingdom', 'Epicentre', 'Honour', 'Fearless', 'Forsaken', 'Genesis',Dark Angel', 'Standing', 'Solitary', 'Beloved' and 'Electronaut'.All the tracks above are great Live with top notch crowd footage and the delightful antics of Ronan on stage. It is not until you see Ronan performing LIVE that you realise and understand how talented and how much heart he puts into each song.Disc 2: Bonus Tour Featurettes/InterviewsThis was my favourite part of the limited edition DVD. It included a 30 minute interview with Ronan and Mark that is insightful to how VNV Nation began and their thoughts and ideas about music and fame in general. You have a short video of tour preparations and stage set up to the theme music of this great future pop outfit. Then you have the 3-city specials and behind the scenes featurette of Ronan and Mark and friends goofing off. Probably the best part was the 'Making of Futureperfect' where Ronan brings the viewer into their makeshift small home studio and gives advice and pointers about music and working with electronica and synths. A small tour.Disc 3: CD-ROM Bonus EditionThis covers the second part of the Interview with Ronan and Mark that carries on from Disc 2. You have two further live in concert performances at different concerts and years of the songs 'Procession' and 'Standing'. You also get a view of the online photo gallery of live pictures and hidden items that can be downloaded.This special edition DVD comes with a poster and a banner sticker that I enjoyed. Overall this DVD is perfect and has shown me more about VNV Nation, their passions, driving force and above all music ideology. I look forward for more future DVD's from this great artist.
Title: N/A

reviewText: To some extent I have to agree with both the supporters and critics of this DVD. The main point should be that VNV is one of the world's premier electronic bands, their music is grand and forceful, and they give excellent, energetic performances. The DVD has the ability to show elements of what makes their shows so good, but fails to fully translate the energy and mystery of actually being there. To me this DVD, despite meticulous editing and wonderful sound quality, is better at highlighting the flaws or what's missing from a VNV show than it is at showing what's great about them. When you are actually there, the power of the music, the majesty of the video accents and passion of Ronan flow directly to you. I have to violently disagree with our friend in SF who claims that VNV is better seen than heard. Their shows are great but this DVD can't capture that magic... had he ever gone to a show he would know that. That is the conclusion that one can draw... not that they are poor live.Having said all of that, I still am glad that I own the DVD. The interviews and extra footage were interesting even though  it's not as insightful as you'd hope from artists with such a painstakingly creative vision. To be honest, I find the Apoptygma Berzerk DVD better although I slightly prefer the music of VNV.
summary: A Good DVD but VNV's Energy Is Hard to Translate
Title: N/A
